content.title: ECMO Vascular Access and Cannulation
content.definition: Vascular surgical techniques for establishing extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) access, including percutaneous and open cannulation, and management of vascular complications.

key_concepts.description: VV-ECMO: veno-venous for respiratory support. VA-ECMO: veno-arterial for cardiac and respiratory support.
Femoral vessels (most common), internal jugular vein, subclavian/axillary vessels, central cannulation (sternotomy).
Critical for VA-ECMO: antegrade limb perfusion cannula prevents leg ischemia from arterial cannula obstruction.

arterial.size: 15-21 Fr depending on patient size and flow requirements
arterial.distal_perfusion: 6-8 Fr antegrade cannula mandatory - insert in SFA or anterior tibial

axillary_subclavian.indication: Need for ambulatory ECMO, peripheral vascular disease, refractory upper body hypoxemia
axillary_subclavian.technique: Open cutdown with side-arm graft sewn to axillary/subclavian artery
axillary_subclavian.advantages: Antegrade aortic flow, allows ambulation, avoids leg ischemia

central.indication: Postcardiotomy failure, right atrial drainage needed
central.technique: Sternotomy with direct cannulation of aorta/right atrium

dual_site.drainage: Femoral vein, tip in IVC/RA junction
dual_site.return: Right internal jugular vein, tip in RA

single_site.technique: Bicaval dual-lumen cannula via right IJ
single_site.disadvantages: Requires TEE for positioning, cannot provide as high flow

limb_ischemia.prevention: Mandatory distal perfusion cannula for VA-ECMO
limb_ischemia.management: Reposition cannula, add/enlarge DPC, compartment release if needed

arterial.pseudoaneurysm: Complication of percutaneous access - repair after decannulation
arterial.dissection: Can occur during cannulation - may require surgical repair

venous.ivc_perforation: Rare but life-threatening - requires immediate surgical intervention
venous.dvt: Common after decannulation - anticoagulation and surveillance

bleeding.management: Local measures, factor replacement, reduce anticoagulation if safe

decannulation.venous: Percutaneous cannulae - manual pressure. Open cannulae - suture closure of venotomy.
decannulation.arterial_percutaneous: Pressure then delayed repair if pseudoaneurysm forms, or primary surgical repair
decannulation.arterial_open: Arteriotomy closure with patch if needed, assess for stenosis

learning_objectives: Differentiate between VV-ECMO and VA-ECMO cannulation strategies
Describe techniques for femoral and axillary arterial cannulation
Explain the importance and technique of distal perfusion in VA-ECMO
List vascular complications of ECMO and their management
clinical_pearls: ALWAYS place distal perfusion cannula for femoral VA-ECMO
Check leg perfusion hourly - limb ischemia progresses rapidly
Bicaval dual-lumen cannula requires TEE guidance for safe placement
Have surgical repair capability available for decannulation
